question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the average of the two smallest positive integer solutions to the congruence $$14u \equiv 46 \pmod{100}~?$$
inference:
**Solution:**
$$14u \equiv 46 \pmod{100}$$
$$14u = 46 + 100k \text{ for some integer } k$$
$$u = \frac{46 + 100k}{14} = 3 + \frac{100k}{14}$$
$$u = 3 + 7k + \frac{3k}{14}$$
$$u = 3 + 7k + \frac{3k}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{7}$$
$$u = 3 + 7k + \frac{3k}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{7} \equiv 3 + 7k \pmod{7}$$
$$u \equiv 3 + 7k \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$u \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$u = 3 + 7n \text{ for some integer } n$$
$$u = 3 + 7n \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$n \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$n = 7m \text{ for some integer } m$$
$$u = 3 + 7n = 3 + 7(7m) = 3 + 49m$$
$$u = 3 + 49m \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$m \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$m = 7p \text{ for some integer } p$$
$$u = 3 + 49m = 3 + 49(7p) = 3 + 343p$$
$$u = 3 + 343p \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$p \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$p = 7q \text{ for some integer } q$$
$$u = 3 + 343p = 3 + 343(7q) = 3 + 2401q$$
$$u = 3 + 2401q \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$q \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$q = 7r \text{ for some integer } r$$
$$u = 3 + 2401q = 3 + 2401(7r) = 3 + 16807r$$
$$u = 3 + 16807r \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$r \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$r = 7s \text{ for some integer } s$$
$$u = 3 + 16807r = 3 + 16807(7s) = 3 + 117649s$$
$$u = 3 + 117649s \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$s \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$s = 7t \text{ for some integer } t$$
$$u = 3 + 117649s = 3 + 117649(7t) = 3 + 823543t$$
$$u = 3 + 823543t \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$t \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$t = 7u \text{ for some integer } u$$
$$u = 3 + 823543t = 3 + 823543(7u) = 3 + 5764801u$$
$$u = 3 + 5764801u \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$u \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$u = 3 + 7v \text{ for some integer } v$$
$$u = 3 + 7v \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$v \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$v = 7w \text{ for some integer } w$$
$$u = 3 + 7v = 3 + 7(7w) = 3 + 49w$$
$$u = 3 + 49w \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$w \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$
$$w = 7x
ground_truth:
Note that $14$, $46$, and $100$ all have a common factor of $2$, so we can divide it out: the solutions to $$14u \equiv 46 \pmod{100}$$ are identical to the solutions to $$7u \equiv 23 \pmod{50}.$$ Make sure you see why this is the case.

Now we can multiply both sides of the congruence by $7$ to obtain $$49u \equiv 161 \pmod{50},$$ which also has the same solutions as the previous congruence, since we could reverse the step above by multiplying both sides by $7^{-1}$. (We know that $7^{-1}$ exists modulo $50$ because $7$ and $50$ are relatively prime.)

Replacing each side of $49u\equiv 161$ by a $\pmod{50}$ equivalent, we have $$-u \equiv 11\pmod{50},$$ and thus $$u \equiv -11\pmod{50}.$$ This is the set of solutions to our original congruence. The two smallest positive solutions are $-11+50 = 39$ and $-11+2\cdot 50 = 89$. Their average is $\boxed{64}$.

$$u = 3 + 49w \equiv 3 \pmod{7}$$
$$w \equiv 0 \pmod{7}$$

ground_truth:
Note that $14$, $46$, and $100$ all have a common factor of $2$, so we can divide it out: the solutions to $$14u \equiv 46 \pmod{100}$$ are identical to the solutions to $$7u \equiv 23 \pmod{50}.$$ Make sure you see why this is the case.

Now we can multiply both sides of the congruence by $7$ to obtain $$49u \equiv 161 \pmod{50},$$ which also has the same solutions as the previous congruence, since we could reverse the step above by multiplying both sides by $7^{-1}$. (We know that $7^{-1}$ exists modulo $50$ because $7$ and $50$ are relatively prime.)

Replacing each side of $49u\equiv 161$ by a $\pmod{50}$ equivalent, we have $$-u \equiv 11\pmod{50},$$ and thus $$u \equiv -11\pmod{50}.$$ This is the set of solutions to our original congruence. The two smallest positive solutions are $-11+50 = 39$ and $-11+2\cdot 50 = 89$. Their average is $\boxed{64}$.
